revised_title: Investigating Variations in Atmospheric Carbon Dioxide in Kew Gardens
tldr: This study examines the variations in carbon dioxide levels in the air of Kew Gardens from 1898 to 1901. The authors found that the average carbon dioxide content was 94 volumes per 10,000 volumes of air, with the highest level recorded at 3.60 parts per 10,000 during a foggy day. They also observed that the carbon dioxide content was generally higher in winter months, but noted an exception in 1901 when July had a higher average. The authors suggest that these variations could impact plant growth and are important for meteorologists and agriculturists to consider.
